message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest nephritis, and among the options, only granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence suggest membranous glomerulonephritis. The other options suggest mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis (C), membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (B), and IgA nephropathy (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s clinical symptoms, laboratory results, and medical history are most consistent with IgA nephropathy, which is associated with granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence. Option A refers to membranous nephropathy, option B refers to thin basement membrane disease, and option C refers to IgA nephropathy on immunofluorescence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest glomerulonephritis, and the presence of protein, RBCs, and RBC casts in the urine supports this. Among the options, only option D (granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence) is characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which can occur after a streptococcal upper respiratory infection like bacterial tonsillitis. Option A is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, option B is characteristic of thin basement membrane disease or Alport syndrome, and option C is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation of periorbital swelling and dark urine, along with laboratory findings of proteinuria, RBCs, and RBC casts, suggests acute glomerulonephritis. The most likely histologic finding would be granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence. Option (A) describes membranous nephropathy, (B) describes Alport syndrome, and (C) describes IgA nephropathy, which are all different types of glomerulonephritis with different histologic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of protein and RBCs in the urine with numerous RBC casts suggests the diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 are indicative of immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. The other options are associated with different types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest the diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Among the options, only option D describes granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence, which is characteristic of post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Option A is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, option B is characteristic of thin basement membrane disease, and option C is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with periorbital swelling and dark urine, which are symptoms of nephrotic syndrome. The presence of RBC casts indicates glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence are the classic findings for membranous glomerulonephritis. Option A describes findings in membranous nephropathy, option B describes findings in thin basement membrane disease, and option C describes findings in IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has periorbital swelling and laboratory studies show proteinuria, hematuria, and RBC casts, suggesting glomerulonephritis. Among the options, only granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence is characteristic of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest glomerulonephritis, and the granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence are characteristic of post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Option A describes membranous nephropathy, option B describes membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and option C describes IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest glomerulonephritis, and among the options, granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence is the most common finding in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis. Spike-and-dome appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy is seen in membranous glomerulopathy, splitting and alternating thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy is seen in thin basement membrane disease, and mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence is seen in IgA nephropathy.
